note.p: Goulan 鉤闌 (literally “restraining” “balustrade” (Kroll) is a railing system that defines the boundaries of constructions and serves both protective and decorative functions. Goulan is used as a safety device in multi-storied structures, podiums, outdoor staircases, and pingzuo 平坐 balconies, as well as outdoor spaces near the edge of water, or on carriages.

The original meaning of the character gou 鉤 is “curved shape." In the compound goulan (鉤闌), the character gou also appears in variant forms such as 句, 勾, and 枸, all conveying the sense of curvature (Duan 1861, 3.3b). In the general commentary on Yingzao Fashi, the gloss of goulan interprets gou as referring to the diagonally intersecting decorative patterns located in the upper portion of the railing (Li 2009, 2.7b). Some scholars, however, propose that gou here specifically denotes goupianzao (鉤片造), a particular decorative motif that was widely used from the Northern Wei through the late Tang and early Song periods (Liu 1980, 124; Liang 2001, 222).

The primary meaning of lan (闌) is "something that obstructs or encloses" (Duan 1861, 12.9b). It is further extended to denote an enclosing structure composed of transverse wooden elements that interlock with one another (Yan 1739, 10.15a). Later, lan came to refer more specifically to the enclosing frameworks around palace complexes, consisting of both horizontal and vertical structural members (Sima 1739, 101.3b).
From the perspective of compound semantics, goulan may thus refer to an enclosing structure adorned with decorative patterns.

The earliest record of the term can be found in Gujing zhu 古今註 (ca. 266 -317 CE)（崔1936，2.1b）where it is used to refer to a railing. The earliest definition of goulan can be found in the Tang dynasty Yiqiejing Yinyi 一切經音義 (ca. AD 627-649 AD), which described it as “the decoration on the edge of the palatial hall, which is also used to prevent people from falling (殿上臨邊之飾也，亦所以防人墜墮也).”

The Song dynasty Yingzao fashi stipulates specific design forms and construction methods for goulan. After the Southern Song dynasty, the term goulan also referred to the performance venue for acrobatics, but was mostly written as 勾欄; its original meaning as an architectural element fell out of use. In Ming and Qing dynasty architectural treatises, such as Luban jing 魯班經 (ca. 1465-1505) and the Gongcheng zuofa 工程做法 (1734), the term, the term langan 欄杆 is used instead of goulan.
鉤闌，供人扶憑或倚仗，防止人墜落的圍護物，用以限定边界，并具装飾功能。鉤闌既可用于樓閣殿亭等建筑物的台基、踏道、平坐和楼梯边沿或两侧，也可用于室外臨空、臨水处或車與之上。

鉤”字的本义是彎曲的形狀，鉤闌中的钩亦作句、勾、枸；均有彎曲的意思（段1861，3.3b）。《营造法式》總釋註解“鉤闌”时引用的“鉤”是指鉤闌之上方斜交错的纹飾（李2009，2.7b）； 也有学者认为此处“鉤”专指鉤片造（谭 2019,21），这种纹样在北魏至唐末宋初时期普遍流行（刘 1980,124；梁 2001,222）。「闌」本义为“遮蔽，围合的事物”（段1861，12.9b），引申为以横木互相贯穿构成的围合物（颜1739，10.15a）。 其後，“闌”也被引申為宫殿四周横向和纵向構件组成的围合物（司马1739，101.3b）。从字义的组合上来看，「鉤闌」或指有纹样装飾的围合物。

鉤闌在文獻中最早見於西晉《古今注》（崔1936，2.1b），““顾成庙有三玉鼎，二真金炉，槐树，悉为扶老鉤欄，画飞云龙角于其上也。””对鉤闌最早的定義见于唐《一切經音義》（玄應1885，1.3a）。北宋《營造法式》 中鉤闌見于“石作”和“小木作”，並對其規定了具體的形制做法。（李1929，3.3b，8.7a）南宋以後，“鉤闌”一詞也指代伎藝的演出場所，多作“勾欄”（孟1805，2.5a） ，而其原有的建築術語意義逐漸淡化。明《魯班經》和清《清工部工程做法则例》 等建築营造专著中，“鉤闌”一词已被“欄杆”所替代。(午1860，1.64a；清工部1734，66.8b)
